dt: {bc}the introduction of a tube into a hollow organ or part (such as the {d_link|trachea|trachea} or stomach) especially to maintain an open passage or gain access to the interior

dt.t: … the neonate experienced respiratory distress that required {wi}intubation{/wi}.

et: The term {it}intubation{/it} was probably introduced in 1885, in the article "Treatment of Croup" by the Illinois physician Frank E. Waxham ({it}The Chicago Medical Journal and Examiner,{/it} vol. 1, no. 6, June, 1885, p. 476). Waxham credits the use of tubes introduced into the trachea as an alternative to tracheotomy to the American physician Joseph O'Dwyer (1841-98). O'Dwyer published an initial report on the procedure as "Intubation of the Larynx," {it}The New York Medical Journal,{/it} vol. 42, issue o August 8, 1885, pp. 145-47. O'Dwyer also uses {it}tubage{/it} for the technique, after the French term used by the physician Eugène Bouchut, who published an earlier description ("D'une nouvelle méthode de traitement du croup par le tubage du larynx," {it}Bulletin de l'Académie de Médecine,{/it} tome 23 [1858], pp. 1160-62).
shortdef: the introduction of a tube into a hollow organ or part (such as the trachea or stomach) especially to maintain an open passage or gain access to the interior
